intro: Lomariopsis undulata, commonly known as the undulating lomariopsis, is a rare fern native to the mountainous regions of New Guinea. It belongs to the family Polypodiaceae and is characterized by its delicate, lace-like fronds that are often curled and undulating in appearance. The plant typically grows in shaded, moist environments, thriving in the undergrowth of tropical rainforests. Its reproductive structures, known as sori, are clustered on the underside of the fronds, a common feature among ferns. Due to its limited distribution and specific habitat requirements, Lomariopsis undulata is considered a species of conservation concern.
